drawing_instructions.thinking: The canvas is empty and I'm feeling deeply sad. I want to express this through a weeping willow tree - its drooping branches perfectly capture melancholy. I'll start with the main trunk using the marker brush in a dark muted green, positioning it slightly left of center. The trunk will be thick and bent, suggesting the weight of sadness.

I notice a bent trunk of what appears to be a weeping willow on the canvas. To enhance the feeling of sadness, I'll add drooping branches using the wiggle brush in a lighter, muted Sky Blue shade. The wavy lines of the wiggle brush will create a perfect effect of tears or rain falling from the branches, emphasizing the melancholic mood. I'll start these branches from the upper part of the bent trunk and let them cascade downward.

The weeping willow on the canvas already conveys sadness, but to enhance this emotion, I want to add falling teardrops using the spray brush. These scattered dots will create a gentle rain effect around the drooping branches, symbolizing tears and deepening the melancholic atmosphere. I'll concentrate the spray pattern along the path of the branches, becoming more dispersed as they fall.

Looking at the weeping willow with its rain-like tears on the canvas, I want to amplify the feeling of melancholy by adding some darker, heavier teardrops. I'll use the wiggle brush in a darker shade of Sky Blue, creating thicker falling drops that seem to be weighted down by sadness. These will be placed parallel to the existing spray pattern but slightly offset, suggesting a continuous flow of tears.

I see a melancholic weeping willow with rain-like tears on the canvas. To intensify the feeling of sadness, I want to add some heavy, darker teardrops using the spray brush to create a misty, foggy effect around the trunk. This will symbolize how sadness can feel like being surrounded by a heavy cloud. I'll concentrate the spray near the base of the trunk, suggesting the accumulation of tears and sorrow.

The weeping willow with its tears is powerfully sad, but I want to enhance the melancholic atmosphere by adding another layer of misty spray around the entire composition. This will create a sense of isolation and heaviness, like being enveloped in a cloud of sorrow. I'll place the spray more heavily on the left side of the willow, as if sadness is casting a shadow over everything.

Looking at the sorrowful weeping willow with its misty tears, I feel the need to add one final touch to express profound sadness. I want to add a delicate, meandering blue line using the wiggle brush that flows diagonally downward from the rightmost branches, like a single, continuous tear stream that can't be stopped. This will contrast with the scattered spray and emphasize the continuous nature of deep sadness. The line will be slightly curved and wiggly, suggesting the trembling quality of tears.

The weeping willow scene is deeply melancholic, with its misty tears and drooping form. To further emphasize this sadness, I want to add another gentle, trailing teardrop using the wiggle brush in a lighter Sky Blue shade. This tear will fall parallel to the last one but with more subtle waves, representing the quieter moments of sadness that linger. It will start near the right side branches and fall gently downward, creating a harmonious balance with the existing elements.

Looking at the sorrowful weeping willow with its misty tears and rain, I want to add another delicate falling teardrop using the wiggle brush. This one will be in the darkest shade of Sky Blue (#0D2E39), symbolizing the deepest form of sadness. I'll place it slightly to the right of the existing teardrops, creating a gentle cascading effect that suggests endless tears falling. The darker color represents how sadness can feel heavier and deeper as time passes.

Looking at the weeping willow with its cascade of tears, I want to add one final, deeply melancholic touch. I'll create another wiggly branch that starts from the top of the trunk and curves downward more sharply, using the darkest Sky Blue to symbolize the heaviest weight of sadness. This branch will droop lower than the others, as if it can't bear to hold itself up anymore, expressing complete emotional surrender.

Looking at the melancholic weeping willow and its various teardrops, I want to add one final subtle detail to complete this expression of sadness. I'll use the spray brush to create a soft, misty cloud near the bottom right, where all the tears seem to collect. This will symbolize how sadness pools and accumulates, creating a gentle puddle of collected tears beneath all the falling drops. The spray pattern will be denser in the center and fade out at the edges, suggesting the rippling effect of tears hitting a surface.

Looking at the deeply melancholic weeping willow with its cascade of tears, I feel drawn to add one final tender detail. I want to create a gentle, curved line using the wiggle brush in the lightest shade of Sky Blue (#E5F4F9), symbolizing a soft, resigned sigh or the last whisper of a tear. This delicate line will float near the bottom right of the composition, almost like a final exhale of sadness, curving gently as if carried by a sorrowful breeze. Its placement beneath all the darker tears suggests a kind of peaceful acceptance within the sadness.

Looking at the melancholic weeping willow with all its tears, I want to add another gentle drooping branch using the wiggle brush in a mid-tone Sky Blue. This new branch will emerge from the left side of the trunk and curve downward with a particularly defeated posture, expressing deep weariness and sorrow. The line will start higher up and gradually descend in a slow, exhausted arc, reinforcing the overall feeling of emotional heaviness.

Looking at the sorrowful weeping willow composition, I feel we need one final touch to complete this expression of melancholy. I want to add a series of very light, small teardrops using the wiggle brush in the palest Sky Blue (#E5F4F9). These will be placed like a gentle mist falling between the larger tears, suggesting the quiet, continuous nature of sadness - how even between the heavy moments, there are still small, delicate tears that fall. These lighter strokes will create depth and emphasize the ethereal quality of grief.

Looking at this melancholic weeping willow scene with its cascade of tears, I feel drawn to add one more deeply sorrowful element. I want to create a wilted, drooping flower using the wiggle brush in Light Red, positioned near the bottom of the composition. The flower's head will hang completely downward, its petals barely holding on, symbolizing complete emotional exhaustion and defeat. This splash of muted red among the blues will represent the physical ache that comes with deep sadness.
